messageBody:
So said tobemligado <jasbell@...> on 2003-01-27
--------------------

>Ok. I see what you are saying. I can make a "Factory" which assures
>the existance of one instance of my "ConfigManager" object. This
>will probably solve the problem since I can "substitute" (make a mock
>object) for the "ConfigManager", or for whatever objects it uses.
>The factory is now the singleton that I must call like so:
>
>MyFactory.getInstance().getConfigManager();
>
>where the returned "ConfigManager" is now an interface or abstract
>class, whose concrete instance may be either a real or mock object.
>
>Is this correct?

That would certainly work.

>I liked your article "Use your singletons wisely", however I did not
>fully grasp the "three questions":
>
>1)Will every application use this class exactly the same way?
>(exactly is the key word)
>2)Will every application ever need only one instance of this class?
>(ever and one are the key words)
>3)Should the clients of this class be unaware of the application they
>are part of?
>
>What is being assumed about the classes use when you ask these three
>questions?

I don't understand your question here.

When considering whether a class should be a singleton, you must ask
yourself those three questions. If you don't answer a resounding YES to
all three, then the class probably does not want to a be singleton, so
don't make it one.

>Thanks again, and great article!

Thanks for the kind words. Even 18 months later, people are getting
some use out of it. I can't be upset about that. :)

-----

You answered, in another e-mail, that you don't want an unsuspecting
programmer to come along and use the second, public constructor by
mistake. This is the biggest problem with global data: it has no
application context; therefore it's unclear that the data belongs to an
application. If data belongs to an application, then ask the
application for it. If there is no natural object that represents the
application (such as a servlet, applet or frame), then create one. In
this case, the Application class would play the role of "toolbox" as I
wrote in my article. Now there's no doubt that it's the Application's
instance of the ConfigManager that application components should use.
In short: "if the config manager belongs to the application, then put
it there."

Hm... that sounds like a good post-script to my article. It's a shame
that developerWorks takes months to respond to e-mail. :)
